Replying to @__ted__ 2018-05-15 17:32
@__ted__ @Netlify These are redirect rules which happen right at the edge nodes of the CDN. This example would behave like a proxypass... invisibly redirecting the user at their nearest CDN node.

Replying to @davatron5000 2018-05-13 20:45
@davatron5000 @github And yep again. The @github API doesn't allow for finer grained permissions. Some people are put off by that, but the authentication happens client-side and @Netlify don't store any creds ourselves after the required hooks are establish for the repo in question.
  • Permalink
  • Twitter
Replying to @davatron5000 2018-05-13 20:42
@davatron5000 @github Yep. Good shout. Sites with lots of assets/pages in particular benefit from plenty of traffic as it thoroughly primes the global CDN caches. If benchmarking it's worth doing some refreshes after each deploy to be sure that you're not going back to the origin for any requests.
